**G.L.\u202fc.\u202f212, \u00a7\u202f4**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4** because the events giving rise to these claims occurred in Norfolk County and the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

**G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231, \u00a7\u202f1**.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this negligence action pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 1** and **c. 223, § 2**, and personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because Defendant conducts business in the Commonwealth.

**c.\u202f223, \u00a7\u202f2**.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this negligence action pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 1** and **c. 223, § 2**, and personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because Defendant conducts business in the Commonwealth.

**G.L.\u202fc.\u202f223A, \u00a7\u202f3*.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this negligence action pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 1** and **c. 223, § 2**, and personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because Defendant conducts business in the Commonwealth.

**G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231, \u00a7\u202f85*.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty constitutes negligence under **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which requires the trier of fact to apportion fault but does not eliminate liability for negligent acts.

**G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231, \u00a7\u202f6B*.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**, and costs.

**Mass.\u202fR.\u202fCiv.\u202fP.\u202f5.proposition: Award statutory interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B** and costs under **Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d)**;

**Mass.\u202fR.\u202fCiv.\u202fP.\u202f3.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. R. Civ. P. 38**, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

**Mounsey\u202fv.\u202fEllard**, 363\u20.proposition: Defendant, as operator of a public restaurant, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep the premises in safe condition and to warn of potential hazards. **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010).

**Papadopoulos\u202fv.\u202fTarget\u202f.proposition: Defendant, as operator of a public restaurant, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep the premises in safe condition and to warn of potential hazards. **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010).

**Oliveri\u202fv.\u202fMass.\u202fBay\u2.raw_text: **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.**, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
**Oliveri\u202fv.\u202fMass.\u202fBay\u2.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability where a defendant had actual or constructive notice of a dangerous condition and failed to act reasonably. **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.**, 363 Mass. 165 (1973); **Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.**, 343 Mass. 263 (1961).

**Deagle\u202fv.\u202fGreat\u202fAtlanti.raw_text: **Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.**, 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
**Deagle\u202fv.\u202fGreat\u202fAtlanti.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability where a defendant had actual or constructive notice of a dangerous condition and failed to act reasonably. **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.**, 363 Mass. 165 (1973); **Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.**, 343 Mass. 263 (1961).

**Boehm\u202fv.\u202fFoxhill\u202fSchool.raw_text: **Boehm v. Foxhill School, Inc.**, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 624 (1988)
**Boehm\u202fv.\u202fFoxhill\u202fSchool.proposition: The duty of care extends to the prevention of foreseeable slip‑and‑fall injuries resulting from unsafe floor conditions. **Boehm v. Foxhill School, Inc.**, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 624 (1988); **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).

**Young\u202fv.\u202fGarwacki**, 380\u20.proposition: The duty of care extends to the prevention of foreseeable slip‑and‑fall injuries resulting from unsafe floor conditions. **Boehm v. Foxhill School, Inc.**, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 624 (1988); **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).

**Brown\u202fv.\u202fWong**, 434\u202fMa.proposition: Defendant failed to establish reasonable inspection and maintenance procedures, contrary to principles articulated in **Brown v. Wong**, 434 Mass. 708 (2001) and **Cragie v. Voe**, 509 F. Supp. 2d 216 (D. Mass. 2007)**.**

**Cragie\u202fv.\u202fVoe**, 509\u202fF..proposition: Defendant failed to establish reasonable inspection and maintenance procedures, contrary to principles articulated in **Brown v. Wong**, 434 Mass. 708 (2001) and **Cragie v. Voe**, 509 F. Supp. 2d 216 (D. Mass. 2007)**.**

**Dos Santos\u202fv.\u202fCarlo\u2019s\u.raw_text: **Dos Santos v. Carlo’s Trucking, Inc.**, 468 Mass. 171 (2014)
**Dos Santos\u202fv.\u202fCarlo\u2019s\u.proposition: The defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence because it fell below the standard of ordinary care that a reasonably prudent restaurant operator would exercise under like circumstances. **Dos Santos v. Carlo’s Trucking, Inc.**, 468 Mass. 171 (2014).

**Leavitt\u202fv.\u202fBrockton\u202fHos.proposition: The injury to Plaintiff was foreseeable and was the natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s neglect. **Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.**, 454 Mass. 37 (2009).

**Kane\u202fv.\u202fFields\u202fCorner\u.raw_text: **Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc.**, 341 Mass. 640 (1961)
**Kane\u202fv.\u202fFields\u202fCorner\u.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, entitling Plaintiff to damages for his medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering. **Restatement (Second) of Torts § 431**; **Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc.**, 341 Mass. 640 (1961).
